Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog

Class RelaxedPlanHeuristic

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.GraphHeuristic
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.GraphHeuristic.MaxGraphHeuristic
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.RelaxedPlanHeuristic
All Implemented Interfaces:
ProgressionCost
public class RelaxedPlanHeuristic extends GraphHeuristic.MaxGraphHeuristic
A graph cost function, meant to be used as the heuristic in a heuristic progression search, which solves a relaxed version of the planning problem and uses the cost of the solution to that relaxed problem as an approximation of the cost of solving the real problem. This heuristic is inspired by Jörg Hoffmann's Fast Forward heuristic.

The relaxed plan heuristic works initializing a max heuristic graph to the state it is evaluating and then extending the graph until it is possible for the node's character's utility to be higher. It then selects a sequence of actions from the heuristic graph that approximate a solution to the problem. Ideally, these actions will be similar to an actual solution to the problem.

The relaxed problem implicitly being solved by this method is as follows: suppose that once a proposition becomes true, it stays true forever. Few real problems have this property, but if we make this assumption about a real problem (even when it doesn't actually hold), we can solve a relaxed version of the problem that is computationally easier. Then we can use the solution to the relaxed problem as an approximation of the solution to the real problem.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware
